accused.name: Catherine veuve Jean Lhuillier
accused.spouse_name: Jean Lhuillier (deceased); married to Christman at time of trial

confession.seduction_context: Owed 19 francs to youth named Petter Britze; his brother Britze was demanding payment so he could arrange marriage. Did not know how she could pay, went out to cut firewood while lamenting. Man in black approached and promised her money if she would renounce God
powder_types: powder made from body of stillborn child, burned and reduced to powder
sabbat_activities: beat water to make snails and other venimeuses reptiles

testimony.quarrel_subject: Dispute over advice during childbirth - accused advised use of force to deliver baby, but witness and another woman opposed this

harms_alleged.target: Appel femme Mathis Hannel and her baby

witnesses.name: Britz
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: client for veterinary services; creditor (accused owed money to Petter Britze)

testimony.quarrel_subject: Accused tried to store personal possessions and grain in witness's house while he and wife were on pilgrimage, claiming they had given permission (which was untrue)

timeline.subject: Catherine Lhuillier
timeline.details: Taken at Cutting after accusations made by Engel and Christienne de Bidestroff, recently executed

timeline.subject: Catherine Lhuillier
timeline.details: Transferred to prison at Dieuze after admitting she was a witch

timeline.subject: Catherine Lhuillier
timeline.details: Substutut for PG de Lorraine asks for further interrogation followed by death sentence

timeline.subject: Catherine Lhuillier
timeline.details: Change de Nancy agrees to death sentence but with requirement for torture

timeline.subject: Catherine Lhuillier
timeline.details: Interrogation under torture - put on rack and tied, but not clear if actually racked. Confessed to killing animals

timeline.subject: Catherine Lhuillier
timeline.details: Change de Nancy agrees to death sentence

torture.restrictions: Accused asked to be treated gently, saying she was feeble and had little flesh on her body. Put on rack and tied, but not clear if actually racked

accomplices_named.name: Scherre Austien
accomplices_named.context: Seen at sabbat in the fields

accomplices_named.name: Demelle femme Welsch Anthoine
accomplices_named.context: Seen at sabbat in the fields

accomplices_named.name: Catherine la hardiere
accomplices_named.context: Seen at sabbat in the fields

accomplices_named.name: Christienne
accomplices_named.context: Seen at sabbat in the fields; recently executed

accomplices_named.name: Engel
accomplices_named.context: Seen at sabbat in the fields; had to return home on foot when both said 'Jesus'. Recently executed

accomplices_named.name: la Vosgienne
accomplices_named.context: Was with her on an occasion when they attacked crops

accomplices_named.name: Ketherine la basle
accomplices_named.context: Seen at similar meeting - but this was later withdrawn (marginal note)

prior_accusations.context: Recently executed; had accused Catherine as accomplice
Recently executed; had accused Catherine as accomplice

notable_quotes.speaker: Catherine Lhuillier
notable_quotes.english: the key to the fields (i.e., she would have fled)
notable_quotes.context: Statement to her guard that if she had known she would be arrested, she would have taken 'la clef des champs' (fled)

notable_quotes.speaker: Agnel (at sabbat)
notable_quotes.english: Jesus, we would die of hunger
notable_quotes.context: Response when the master told them they must go and waste corn at the sabbat

notable_quotes.speaker: Catherine Lhuillier (at sabbat)
notable_quotes.context: When told to beat water to make snails and venimeuses reptiles, she said 'Jesus' and everything vanished

relationships.evidence_text: Catherine veuve Jean Lhuillier; married Jean Lhuillier, with whom she was for 19 years
Had married Christman, manouvrier and hardier des bestes a cornes
daughter of Didier Noirel, vigneron, and his wife Claude
Didier Noirel, vigneron, and his wife Claude
coming to Domnon, wher she had a sister-in-law
Agnelle femme Gros Hans de Bidestroff
Owed 19 francs to youth named Petter Britze
his brother Britze was demanding payment

economic_context.details: Catherine owed 19 francs to Petter Britze, and his brother was demanding payment so he could arrange marriage. This debt was explicitly mentioned as the context for her seduction by the devil - she was lamenting her inability to pay when the devil approached her.

harms_catalog.victim_name: Appel femme Mathis Hannel and her baby
harms_catalog.harm_description: Potential harm to mother and child during childbirth - witness believed if they had followed accused's advice to use force, both mother and child would have perished
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Dispute over midwifery advice during childbirth
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: Baby born a day later; harm was potential/avoided

harms_catalog.method_alleged: Unclear - witness called her to cure them; sometimes she cured them, other times not
Using drink made from body of stillborn child, burned and reduced to powder; group would hold animal while this was administered
Sabbat activities - told by master to waste corn; la Vosgienne was with her when they attacked crops

material_culture.context: Given by devil to mount in the name of devils to be carried to sabbat in the fields
One of the items used to be carried off to sabbat
One of the items used to be carried off to sabbat
One of the items used to be carried off to sabbat
Musical instrument played at sabbat for dancing; played by a vagabond with a limp
Body of stillborn child burned and reduced to powder, made into drink used to kill animals
Devil promised her money if she renounced God; told her not to look at it until she got home, when it turned out to be cinders
Accused tried to store these at Britz's house while he was on pilgrimage; servants refused them
She went out to cut firewood while lamenting her debt; was picking up bundle when devil threw her down
Brought to Britz's house claiming they had given permission to store them (which was untrue)

spatial_references.context: Primary location of trial; where accused resided for 9 years
Where informations preparatoires were taken; home of some accomplices
Home of Engel and Christienne who accused Catherine; location of executions
Prison location where Catherine was transferred on 9 June 1594; location of executions
Where Catherine lived for about 4 years
Where Catherine married Jean Lhuillier and lived for 19 years
Home of Scherre Austien, accomplice seen at sabbat
Location of sabbat where she found 5 others; where they danced and were told to waste corn
Where she went to cut firewood while lamenting her debt; where devil approached her
Pilgrimage destination where Britz and his wife went

weather_events: raining hard when returning from sabbat - accused and Engel had to return home on foot, all wet
economic_hardship_indicators: Catherine went begging around villages with a sick child after her first husband's death
Owed 19 francs she could not pay, which precipitated her alleged seduction by the devil
Was in such poverty that she was lamenting while cutting firewood
Tried to store personal possessions and grain at another person's house, suggesting displacement or economic instability

legal_context.imprisonment_conditions: Transferred to prison at Dieuze on 9 June after admitting she was a witch; guard appointed (Mathzen Hanns) because she had tried to flee several times

hearsay_chains.content: vigneron told accused she would not be arrested until after execution of those held at Dieuze or Biderstroff
She had said a vigneron had told her she would not be arrested until after executions at Dieuze or Bidestroff
Had heard nothing against her until recent execution (implying learned of accusations from executed witches)
Over last year there had been talk of reputation

emotional_state_notes: Tried to flee several times before arrest
Said she would have taken 'la clef des champs' (fled) if she had known she would be arrested
Asked to be treated gently during torture, saying she was feeble and had little flesh on her body

third_parties.context: Woman giving birth who accused supposedly gave dangerous midwifery advice to

third_parties.name: maire Hannel
third_parties.context: Mayor of Domnon; husband of first witness

third_parties.name: sick child of Catherine
third_parties.context: Catherine went begging around villages with a sick child after her first husband's death

third_parties.name: Petter Britze
third_parties.context: Youth to whom Catherine owed 19 francs

third_parties.name: Britze (brother of Petter)
third_parties.context: Was demanding payment of the 19 francs so he could arrange marriage

third_parties.name: unnamed vigneron
third_parties.context: Told Catherine she would not be arrested until after executions at Dieuze or Bidestroff

third_parties.name: another woman (unnamed)
third_parties.context: Was with witness 1 and opposed accused's advice during childbirth

third_parties.name: servants of Britz
third_parties.context: Refused to accept accused's grain in absence of master and mistress

third_parties.name: wife of Britz
third_parties.context: Went on pilgrimage to St Nicolas with husband

extraction_metadata.notes: This is a rich trial record with detailed witness testimony and extensive confession narrative. The case was triggered by accusations from recently executed witches (Engel and Christienne de Bidestroff). Notable features include: (1) weak witness testimony - most witnesses knew nothing against her or only recent rumor; (2) economic distress as trigger for alleged devil pact (19 franc debt); (3) interesting sabbat narrative with invocation of Jesus causing disruption; (4) confession expanded under torture; (5) relatively rapid timeline from arrest to execution (29 days); (6) Rémy (the famous witch-hunter and author of Daemonolatreiae) was the prosecutor. The case illustrates the chain-reaction nature of witch trials, with accusations from executed witches triggering new arrests.
